qas.question: From what source does information of Roman thought about the afterlife come?
What type of practices were those affecting the care of the dead?
What did the ancient Romans expect after death?
With whom did the  early Romans expect to associate?
What did later Romans invest in rather than grave offerings?

context: Roman beliefs about an afterlife varied, and are known mostly for the <a0_0>educated elite<a0_0/> who expressed their views in terms of their chosen philosophy. The traditional care of the dead, however, and the perpetuation after death of their status in life were part of the most <a1_0>archaic<a1_0/> practices of Roman religion. Ancient votive deposits to the noble dead of Latium and Rome suggest elaborate and costly funeral offerings and banquets in the company of the deceased, an expectation of <a2_0>afterlife<a2_0/> and their association with the <a3_0>gods<a3_0/>. As Roman society developed, its Republican nobility tended to invest less in spectacular funerals and extravagant housing for their dead, and more on <a4_0>monumental endowments<a4_0/> to the community, such as the donation of a temple or public building whose donor was commemorated by his statue and inscribed name. Persons of low or negligible status might receive simple burial, with such grave goods as relatives could afford.
